titleStmt.title: To Theo van Gogh. The Hague, Tuesday, 28 January 1873.

vg:letContents.p: To Theo van Gogh. The Hague, Tuesday, 28 January 1873.

note.p: Amsterdam, Van Gogh Museum, inv. no. b4 V/1962

ab.tei:seg: ik ben blij dat je het naar
je zin hebt & het goed hebt
is, dat komt later alles te
het begin doen wat hij wel
Wat heb ik medelijden met Oom
Hein, ik hoop zoo van harte
dat hij nog beter zal worden,
maar Theo, ik vrees er voor.–
Van de zomer was hij nog
mij dat de zaken zoo goed
Verl. Zondag ben ik bij Oom
zoo als je denken kunt veel
is Oom pas naar Parijs geweest
ik best, het Trippenhuis is te
zóó dat men ze niet goed
Wat zou ik graag dat Sch
mooi. Schrijf mij eens of dat
is, of hoe anders den voornaam
is. De photogr. naar Rotta ken
wat je alzoo ziet, dat doet
hebt opgegeven is het bedoelde niet;
dat zijn alleen lithogr. naar Corot.–
Ik bedank je echter voor de genomen
Ik wacht binnen kort een brief
die is nog al lui met
haar eens verrassen met een brief,
dat zou haar zooveel pleizier doen.
Je zult het wel druk hebben;
Het is hier koud & men rijdt
ik wandel zooveel als ik kan.
Ik ben nieuwsgierig of je nog
weet is het voor Pa’s verjaardag.
Ik feliciteer je daar al vast
Je moet compliment hebben van allen

It’s good that you answered me so quickly. I’m glad that things are to your liking and that you’ve been lucky with your boarding-house. Be of good heart if things sometimes get difficult, everything will come right later on, and no one can do what he really wants in the beginning.
. I sincerely hope he’ll get better, but Theo, I fear he won’t. Last summer he was still
so full of ambition, and had so many plans and told me that business was going so well. It is indeed sad.

and had a very pleasant day there and, as you can well imagine, saw many beautiful things. As you know, Uncle has just been to Paris and has brought home splendid paintings and drawings. I stayed in Amsterdam on Monday morning and went to the museums again. Did you know that a large, new building will take the place of the Trippenhuis in Amsterdam? That’s fine with me; the Trippenhuis is too small, and many paintings hang in such a way that one can’t see them properly.
How I’d like to see that painting by
I’ve seen only a few of his paintings,
and those I find very beautiful. Write and tell me whether that other painting is by
or otherwise what his Christian name is. I know the photo of the
and even saw the painting at the Brussels exhibition.
Do keep me constantly informed about whatever you see, that always gives me pleasure. The album whose title you gave me isn’t the one I meant, which contains only lithographs after Corot.
Thanks anyway for taking the trouble.
She’s rather lazy about writing these days. You ought to surprise her with a letter sometime, that would give her so much pleasure. You must be very busy, but that’s a good thing.

It’s cold here, and people are already skating on the flooded fields. I go walking as much as I can. I’m curious to know whether you’ll find an opportunity to go skating. Herewith my portrait, but don’t say anything about it when you write home. As you know, it’s for
on which I congratulate you ahead of the event.
’ send you their compliments. Adieu, I wish you well.

note.ab: Poor health had forced Uncle Hein to retire from art dealing in 1872.
Cornelis (Cor) Marinus van Gogh, brother of Mr van Gogh and often called ‘C.M.’ by family members, had a bookshop and art gallery at Keizersgracht 453 in Amsterdam.

The Rijksmuseum was housed at the time in the so-called Trippenhuis at Kloveniersburgwal 29 in Amsterdam. The building’s accommodations and suitability were the object of much criticism. See Honderd jaar Rijksmuseum 1985.
It is not known which painting by Alfred Cluysenaar this refers to.

The following works by Cluysenaar were on display at the Brussels Salon which Van Gogh had visited in 1872: Mazeppa; Portraits de MM. Paul et Edmond R. (Mazeppa; Portraits of Messieurs Paul and Edmond R.) and a Portrait (Portrait). See exhib. cat. Brussels 1872, p. 30, cat. nos. 114-116.
Van Gogh underlined the Christian name of Alfred to distinguish him from his brother Joseph Stevens, who was also a painter.

Antonio Rotta was represented at Brussels by the painting Il ciabattino (The cobbler). Exhib. cat. Brussels 1872, p. 78, cat. no. 639. Three works bearing this title and depicting similar themes have been found, an example being At the cobbler’s, 1867 (present whereabouts unknown), sold at Christie’s (London) on 24 June 1988 (no. 43). Ill. 1295.

In the summer of 1872, Van Gogh had visited the triennial salon, ‘Exposition générale des Beaux-Arts’ (General Exhibition of Fine Arts) at Brussels, which was held from 15 August to 15 October; see letter 13.

The way in which he asked about the album in letter 3 suggests that Van Gogh was referring to the album of lithographs by Emile Louis Vernier after work by Camille Corot. Apparently Theo had sent the title of an album containing work by Corot.
Anna Cornelia van Gogh, Van Gogh’s eldest sister, was attending boarding school in Leeuwarden in the north of the Netherlands.
Mr van Gogh would turn 51 on 8 February.
Uncle Hein and Aunt Mietje in Brussels.
Sophia (Fie) Cornelia Elisabeth Carbentus-Van Bemmel, wife of Arie Carbentus, brother of Mrs van Gogh.
